preface.title: Preface
preface.para: Apache Isis is designed to allow programmers rapidly develop domain-driven applications following the Naked Objects pattern. It is made up of a core framework that supports supports various viewers, along with APIs and implementations relating to security, the programming model, the runtime (persistence) and profile stores (user preferences). Apache Isis is hosted at the Apache Foundation, and is licensed under Apache Software License v2.

The security API covers authentication and authorization. A number of different security implementations, and this guide explains how to configure them, as well as how to go about implementing your own implementation.

sect1.title: Who this Guide is For
sect1.para:
This guide is written for deployers looking to configure Isis to run with a specific existing security implementation, and for programmers wishing to develop their own custom implementation. It is divided into the following parts:
Isis Security Implementations
This part of the guide (see ) covers the default (Java 5) programming model, how to customize it, and how to extend it.
Writing a Custom Implementation
This part of the guide (see ) describes how to go about writing your own custom implementation of the security API.
Configuring the Runtime
This part of the guide (see ) describes how to configure your application to use a specified security implementation.

sect1.title: How this Guide relates to other Documentation
sect1.para: The core documentation [oai:core] describes the security API as defined by the core runtime [oai.core:runtime]. The runtime documentation (for example the default runtime module [oai.runtimes:dflt]) will describe how to configure security, but for convenience the configuration information is also provided in this guide also.

partintro.para: Apache Isis applications support authentication ("who are you"?) and authorization ("what can you do?"). This allows the set of functionality to be restricted based upon the user's role, with no security knowledge needing to be embedded within the domain objects.

From the domain objects persepective the user is represented as the UserMemento and RoleMemento values (in the oai.applib.security package), but within the framework the user is represented by an AuthenticationSession object. From this session object can be obtained the name of the user and their roles.

The security API is defined in the core runtime module [oai.core:runtime] by the AuthenticationManager interface and the AuthorizationManager interface. Isis has a number of implementations of both: a default (no-op) implementation, a simple file-based implementation and an LDAP implementation. The default for the authentication manager depends on the runtime;

If no authorization manager has been specified, then all domain properties, collections and actions will be available to all users. When an authorization manager is configured, it can be used to authorise the visibility ("can you see it?") and usability ("can you use it?") of properties/collections and actions independently. This is done with respect to the roles that are assigned to the user. Thus an object member may be visible to certain roles but not editable.

It is possible, if required, to mix-and-match implementations. For example, authentication could be using LDAP, but authorization could be done using file-based implementation or a custom implementation.

sect1.title: Authorization
sect1.para: Authorization allows access to actions and properties to be controlled by configuration.

sect2.title: Authorization through 'allow' and 'disallow' files
sect2.para: With file authorization the current user's role will be authorised against a white and (optionally) a black list for each method possibly available to them. The files are identified by properties, e.g.
The white list file is mandatory, if there is no property it defaults to security_file.allow, and is picked up from the same location as the isis.properties configuration file.

The black list file is optional; the presence of the property indicates it is being used. If the white list file default is being used then we recommend security_file.disallow as the name of the black list file. Again, it is picked up from the same location as isis.properties configuration file.
The settings can then be modified to conform to the required security settings.

sect2.title: Matching
sect2.para:
Each file contains a signature to match against and a list of roles, which follow the same
A match in the white list file permits the access
A match in the black list forbids it the access
The black list overrides the white list
Matching occurs at three levels class, method (or property) and parameters
Property matches are to the bean property name e.g. 'phone' for getPhone and setPhone.

sect2.para: The files are formatted as follows:

sect2.title: Auto-learn
sect2.para: As a tool for helping to configure the initial security settings there is a 'learn' property.

When this is present and set, all methods will be authorised for all roles. However as each method is accessed through the user interface authorization will be configured for that method and the current role. The idea is to these files can then be used as the basis for explicit configuration once auto-learn is disabled.

sect1.title: Authorization
sect1.para: With LDAP authorization the current user's role will be authorised against an entry in the LDAP server for each method possibly available to them. The URL of the server is obtained from the same property as for authentication.
The authorization entries should exist under a DN configured in the property file. For example.
This will be checked anonymously.

Entries to be matched against should exist under this dn. Expected configuration is a hierarchy of class, method and parameters. The cn of each entry is expected to be the fully qualified class name, method or parameter list ('()' for an empty parameter list). If an entry has a 'uniquemember' attribute equal to 'role' then that entry and all sub-entries are authorised.

sect1.para:
There is an optional capability to authorise the visibility and usability of fields independently. Thus a field may be visible to certain roles but not editable. In order to configure this against a authorization a flag must be added by setting a "flags" attribute to the entry with the role.
If it is set to 'rw' then editing will be allowed,
If it is set to any other value (typically 'ro') then editing is disallowed
In each case absence of the flag will mean that visibility and usability and are always the same.
